#### [6.1.3.](#section-6.1.3){.section-number .selfRef} [Sending Application Probe Packets](#name-sending-application-probe-p){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-sending-application-probe-p}

A probe packet can carry an application data block, but the successful
transmission of this data is at risk when used for probing. Some
applications might prefer to use a probe packet that does not carry an
application data block to avoid disruption of data
transfer.[¶](#section-6.1.3-1){.pilcrow}
:::
:::

::: {#section-6.1.4 .section}
#### [6.1.4.](#section-6.1.4){.section-number .selfRef} [Initial Connectivity](#name-initial-connectivity){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-initial-connectivity}

An application that does not have other higher-layer information
confirming connectivity with the remote peer [SHOULD]{.bcp14} implement
a connectivity mechanism using acknowledged probe packets before
entering the BASE state.[¶](#section-6.1.4-1){.pilcrow}
:::

::: {#section-6.1.5 .section}
#### [6.1.5.](#section-6.1.5){.section-number .selfRef} [Validating the Path](#name-validating-the-path){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-validating-the-path}

An application that does not have other higher-layer information
confirming correct delivery of datagrams [SHOULD]{.bcp14} implement the
CONFIRMATION_TIMER to periodically send probe packets while in the
SEARCH_COMPLETE state.[¶](#section-6.1.5-1){.pilcrow}
:::

::: {#udpopt_ptb_handling}
::: {#section-6.1.6 .section}
#### [6.1.6.](#section-6.1.6){.section-number .selfRef} [Handling of PTB Messages](#name-handling-of-ptb-messages){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-handling-of-ptb-messages}

An application that is able and wishes to receive PTB messages
[MUST]{.bcp14} perform ICMP validation as specified in [Section
5.2](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8085#section-5.2){.relref} of
\[[BCP145](#BCP145){.xref}\]. This requires that the application checks
each received PTB message to validate that it was is received in
response to transmitted traffic and that the reported PL_PTB_SIZE is
less than the current probed size (see [Section
4.6.2](#validPTB_SIZE){.xref}). A validated PTB message [MAY]{.bcp14} be
used as input to the DPLPMTUD algorithm but [MUST NOT]{.bcp14} be used
directly to set the PLPMTU.[¶](#section-6.1.6-1){.pilcrow}
:::
:::
:::

::: {#section-6.2 .section}
### [6.2.](#section-6.2){.section-number .selfRef} [DPLPMTUD for SCTP](#name-dplpmtud-for-sctp){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-dplpmtud-for-sctp}

[Section
10.2](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4821#section-10.2){.relref} of
\[[RFC4821](#RFC4821){.xref}\] specifies a recommended PLPMTUD probing
method for SCTP, and [Section
7.3](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4960#section-7.3){.relref} of
\[[RFC4960](#RFC4960){.xref}\] recommends an endpoint apply the
techniques in RFC 4821 on a per-destination-address basis. The
specification for DPLPMTUD continues the practice of using the PL to
discover the PMTU but updates RFC4960 with a recommendation to use the
method specified in this document: The [RECOMMENDED]{.bcp14} method for
generating probes is to add a chunk consisting only of padding to an
SCTP message. The PAD chunk defined in \[[RFC4820](#RFC4820){.xref}\]
[SHOULD]{.bcp14} be attached to a minimum-length HEARTBEAT (HB) chunk to
build a probe packet. This enables probing without affecting the
transfer of user messages and without being limited by congestion
control or flow control. This is preferred to using DATA chunks (with
padding as required) as path probes.[¶](#section-6.2-1){.pilcrow}

[Section
6.9](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4960#section-6.9){.relref} of
\[[RFC4960](#RFC4960){.xref}\] describes dividing the user messages into
DATA chunks sent by the PL when using SCTP. This notes that once an SCTP
message has been sent, it cannot be resegmented.
\[[RFC4960](#RFC4960){.xref}\] describes the method for retransmitting
DATA chunks when the MPS has been reduced, and [Section
6.9](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4960#section-6.9){.relref} of
\[[RFC4960](#RFC4960){.xref}\] describes use of IP fragmentation for
this case. This is unchanged by this
document.[¶](#section-6.2-2){.pilcrow}

::: {#sctp_over_ip}
::: {#section-6.2.1 .section}
#### [6.2.1.](#section-6.2.1){.section-number .selfRef} [SCTP/IPv4 and SCTP/IPv6](#name-sctp-ipv4-and-sctp-ipv6){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-sctp-ipv4-and-sctp-ipv6}

::: {#section-6.2.1.1 .section}
##### [6.2.1.1.](#section-6.2.1.1){.section-number .selfRef} [Initial Connectivity](#name-initial-connectivity-2){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-initial-connectivity-2}

The base protocol is specified in \[[RFC4960](#RFC4960){.xref}\]. This
provides an acknowledged PL. A sender can therefore enter the BASE state
as soon as connectivity has been
confirmed.[¶](#section-6.2.1.1-1){.pilcrow}
:::

::: {#sctp_over_ip_probing}
::: {#section-6.2.1.2 .section}
##### [6.2.1.2.](#section-6.2.1.2){.section-number .selfRef} [Sending SCTP Probe Packets](#name-sending-sctp-probe-packets){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-sending-sctp-probe-packets}

Probe packets consist of an SCTP common header followed by a HEARTBEAT
chunk and a PAD chunk. The PAD chunk is used to control the length of
the probe packet. The HEARTBEAT chunk is used to trigger the sending of
a HEARTBEAT ACK chunk. The reception of the HEARTBEAT ACK chunk
acknowledges reception of a successful probe. A successful probe updates
the association and path counters, but an unsuccessful probe is
discounted (assumed to be a result of choosing too large a
PLPMTU).[¶](#section-6.2.1.2-1){.pilcrow}

The SCTP sender needs to be able to determine the total size of a probe
packet. The HEARTBEAT chunk could carry a Heartbeat Information
parameter that includes, besides the information suggested in
\[[RFC4960](#RFC4960){.xref}\], the probe size to help an implementation
associate a HEARTBEAT ACK with the size of probe that was sent. The
sender could also use other methods, such as sending a nonce and
verifying the information returned also contains the corresponding
nonce. The length of the PAD chunk is computed by reducing the probing
size by the size of the SCTP common header and the HEARTBEAT chunk. The
payload of the PAD chunk contains arbitrary data. When transmitted at
the IP layer, the PMTU size also includes the IPv4 or IPv6
header(s).[¶](#section-6.2.1.2-2){.pilcrow}

Probing can start directly after the PL handshake; this can be done
before data is sent. Assuming this behavior (i.e., the PMTU is smaller
than or equal to the interface MTU), this process will take several
round-trip time periods, dependent on the number of DPLPMTUD probes
sent. The Heartbeat timer can be used to implement the
PROBE_TIMER.[¶](#section-6.2.1.2-3){.pilcrow}
:::
:::

::: {#section-6.2.1.3 .section}
##### [6.2.1.3.](#section-6.2.1.3){.section-number .selfRef} [Validating the Path with SCTP](#name-validating-the-path-with-sc){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-validating-the-path-with-sc}

Since SCTP provides an acknowledged PL, a sender [MUST NOT]{.bcp14}
implement the CONFIRMATION_TIMER while in the SEARCH_COMPLETE
state.[¶](#section-6.2.1.3-1){.pilcrow}
:::

::: {#sctp_over_ip_ptb_handling}
::: {#section-6.2.1.4 .section}
##### [6.2.1.4.](#section-6.2.1.4){.section-number .selfRef} [PTB Message Handling by SCTP](#name-ptb-message-handling-by-sct){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-ptb-message-handling-by-sct}

Normal ICMP validation [MUST]{.bcp14} be performed as specified in
[Appendix C](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4960#appendix-C){.relref}
of \[[RFC4960](#RFC4960){.xref}\]. This requires that the first 8 bytes
of the SCTP common header are quoted in the payload of the PTB message,
which can be the case for ICMPv4 and is normally the case for
ICMPv6.[¶](#section-6.2.1.4-1){.pilcrow}

When a PTB message has been validated, the PL_PTB_SIZE calculated from
the PTB_SIZE reported in the PTB message [SHOULD]{.bcp14} be used with
the DPLPMTUD algorithm, provided that the reported PL_PTB_SIZE is less
than the current probe size (see [Section
4.6](#mechanism-ptb){.xref}).[¶](#section-6.2.1.4-2){.pilcrow}
:::
:::
:::
:::

::: {#section-6.2.2 .section}
#### [6.2.2.](#section-6.2.2){.section-number .selfRef} [DPLPMTUD for SCTP/UDP](#name-dplpmtud-for-sctp-udp){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-dplpmtud-for-sctp-udp}

The UDP encapsulation of SCTP is specified in
\[[RFC6951](#RFC6951){.xref}\].[¶](#section-6.2.2-1){.pilcrow}

This specification updates the reference to RFC 4821 in Section
[5.6](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6951#section-5.6){.relref} of
RFC 6951 to refer to this document (RFC 8899). RFC 6951 is updated by
the addition of the following sentence at the end of Section
[5.6](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6951#section-5.6){.relref}:[¶](#section-6.2.2-2){.pilcrow}

> The [RECOMMENDED]{.bcp14} method for determining the MTU of the path
> is specified in RFC 8899.[¶](#section-6.2.2-3.1){.pilcrow}

::: {#section-6.2.2.1 .section}
##### [6.2.2.1.](#section-6.2.2.1){.section-number .selfRef} [Initial Connectivity](#name-initial-connectivity-3){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-initial-connectivity-3}

A sender can enter the BASE state as soon as SCTP connectivity has been
confirmed.[¶](#section-6.2.2.1-1){.pilcrow}
:::

::: {#sctp_over_udp_probing}
::: {#section-6.2.2.2 .section}
##### [6.2.2.2.](#section-6.2.2.2){.section-number .selfRef} [Sending SCTP/UDP Probe Packets](#name-sending-sctp-udp-probe-pack){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-sending-sctp-udp-probe-pack}

Packet probing can be performed as specified in [Section
6.2.1.2](#sctp_over_ip_probing){.xref}. The size of the probe packet
includes the 8 bytes of UDP header. This has to be considered when
filling the probe packet with the PAD
chunk.[¶](#section-6.2.2.2-1){.pilcrow}
:::
:::

::: {#section-6.2.2.3 .section}
##### [6.2.2.3.](#section-6.2.2.3){.section-number .selfRef} [Validating the Path with SCTP/UDP](#name-validating-the-path-with-sct){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-validating-the-path-with-sct}

SCTP provides an acknowledged PL; therefore, a sender does not implement
the CONFIRMATION_TIMER while in the SEARCH_COMPLETE
state.[¶](#section-6.2.2.3-1){.pilcrow}
:::

::: {#sctp_over_udp_ptb_handling}
::: {#section-6.2.2.4 .section}
##### [6.2.2.4.](#section-6.2.2.4){.section-number .selfRef} [Handling of PTB Messages by SCTP/UDP](#name-handling-of-ptb-messages-by){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-handling-of-ptb-messages-by}

ICMP validation [MUST]{.bcp14} be performed for PTB messages as
specified in [Appendix
C](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4960#appendix-C){.relref} of
\[[RFC4960](#RFC4960){.xref}\]. This requires that the first 8 bytes of
the SCTP common header are contained in the PTB message, which can be
the case for ICMPv4 (but note the UDP header also consumes a part of the
quoted packet header) and is normally the case for ICMPv6. When the
validation is completed, the PL_PTB_SIZE calculated from the PTB_SIZE in
the PTB message [SHOULD]{.bcp14} be used with the DPLPMTUD providing
that the reported PL_PTB_SIZE is less than the current probe
size.[¶](#section-6.2.2.4-1){.pilcrow}
:::
:::
:::

::: {#section-6.2.3 .section}
#### [6.2.3.](#section-6.2.3){.section-number .selfRef} [DPLPMTUD for SCTP/DTLS](#name-dplpmtud-for-sctp-dtls){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-dplpmtud-for-sctp-dtls}

The Datagram Transport Layer Security (DTLS) encapsulation of SCTP is
specified in \[[RFC8261](#RFC8261){.xref}\]. This is used for data
channels in WebRTC implementations. This specification updates the
reference to RFC 4821 in Section
[5](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8261#section-5){.relref} of RFC
8261 to refer to this document (RFC
8899).[¶](#section-6.2.3-1){.pilcrow}

::: {#section-6.2.3.1 .section}
##### [6.2.3.1.](#section-6.2.3.1){.section-number .selfRef} [Initial Connectivity](#name-initial-connectivity-4){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-initial-connectivity-4}

A sender can enter the BASE state as soon as SCTP connectivity has been
confirmed.[¶](#section-6.2.3.1-1){.pilcrow}
:::

::: {#sctp_over_dtls_probing}
::: {#section-6.2.3.2 .section}
##### [6.2.3.2.](#section-6.2.3.2){.section-number .selfRef} [Sending SCTP/DTLS Probe Packets](#name-sending-sctp-dtls-probe-pac){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-sending-sctp-dtls-probe-pac}

Packet probing can be done as specified in [Section
6.2.1.2](#sctp_over_ip_probing){.xref}. The maximum payload is reduced
by the size of the DTLS headers, which has to be considered when filling
the PAD chunk. The size of the probe packet includes the DTLS PL
headers. This has to be considered when filling the probe packet with
the PAD chunk.[¶](#section-6.2.3.2-1){.pilcrow}
:::
:::

::: {#section-6.2.3.3 .section}
##### [6.2.3.3.](#section-6.2.3.3){.section-number .selfRef} [Validating the Path with SCTP/DTLS](#name-validating-the-path-with-sctp){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-validating-the-path-with-sctp}

Since SCTP provides an acknowledged PL, a sender [MUST NOT]{.bcp14}
implement the CONFIRMATION_TIMER while in the SEARCH_COMPLETE
state.[¶](#section-6.2.3.3-1){.pilcrow}
:::

::: {#sctp_over_dtls_ptb_handling}
::: {#section-6.2.3.4 .section}
##### [6.2.3.4.](#section-6.2.3.4){.section-number .selfRef} [Handling of PTB Messages by SCTP/DTLS](#name-handling-of-ptb-messages-by-){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-handling-of-ptb-messages-by-}

\[[RFC4960](#RFC4960){.xref}\] does not specify a way to validate
SCTP/DTLS ICMP message payload and neither does this document. This can
prevent processing of PTB messages at the
PL.[¶](#section-6.2.3.4-1){.pilcrow}
:::
:::
:::
:::

::: {#section-6.3 .section}
### [6.3.](#section-6.3){.section-number .selfRef} [DPLPMTUD for QUIC](#name-dplpmtud-for-quic){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-dplpmtud-for-quic}

QUIC \[[QUIC](#I-D.ietf-quic-transport){.xref}\] is a UDP-based PL that
provides reception feedback. The UDP payload includes a QUIC packet
header, a protected payload, and any authentication fields. It supports
padding and packet coalescence that can be used to construct probe
packets. From the perspective of DPLPMTUD, QUIC can function as an
acknowledged PL. \[[QUIC](#I-D.ietf-quic-transport){.xref}\] describes
the method for using DPLPMTUD with QUIC
packets.[¶](#section-6.3-1){.pilcrow}
:::
:::
:::

::: {#IANA}
::: {#section-7 .section}
## [7.](#section-7){.section-number .selfRef} [IANA Considerations](#name-iana-considerations){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-iana-considerations}

This document has no IANA actions.[¶](#section-7-1){.pilcrow}
:::
:::

::: {#Security}
::: {#section-8 .section}
## [8.](#section-8){.section-number .selfRef} [Security Considerations](#name-security-considerations){.section-name .selfRef} {#name-security-considerations}

The security considerations for the use of UDP and SCTP are provided in
the referenced RFCs.[¶](#section-8-1){.pilcrow}

To avoid excessive load, the interval between individual probe packets
[MUST]{.bcp14} be at least one RTT, and the interval between rounds of
probing is determined by the
PMTU_RAISE_TIMER.[¶](#section-8-2){.pilcrow}

A PL sender needs to ensure that the method used to confirm reception of
probe packets protects from off-path attackers injecting packets into
the path. This protection is provided in IETF-defined protocols (e.g.,
TCP, SCTP) using a randomly initialized sequence number. A description
of one way to do this when using UDP is provided in Section
[5.1](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8085#section-5.1){.relref} of
\[[BCP145](#BCP145){.xref}\]).[¶](#section-8-3){.pilcrow}

There are cases where ICMP Packet Too Big (PTB) messages are not
delivered due to policy, configuration, or equipment design (see
[Section 1.1](#Classic-PMTUD){.xref}). This method therefore does not
rely upon PTB messages being received but is able to utilize these when
they are received by the sender. PTB messages could potentially be used
to cause a node to inappropriately reduce the PLPMTU. A node supporting
DPLPMTUD [MUST]{.bcp14} therefore appropriately validate the payload of
PTB messages to ensure these are received in response to transmitted
traffic (i.e., a reported error condition that corresponds to a datagram
actually sent by the path layer, see [Section
4.6.1](#PTB){.xref}).[¶](#section-8-4){.pilcrow}

An on-path attacker able to create a PTB message could forge PTB
messages that include a valid quoted IP packet. Such an attack could be
used to drive down the PLPMTU. An on-path device could similarly force a
reduction of the PLPMTU by implementing a policy that drops packets
larger than a configured size. There are two ways this method can be
mitigated against such attacks: first, by ensuring that a PL sender
never reduces the PLPMTU below the base size solely in response to
receiving a PTB message. This is achieved by first entering the BASE
state when such a message is received. Second, the design does not
require processing of PTB messages; a PL sender could therefore suspend
processing of PTB messages (e.g., in a robustness mode after detecting
that subsequent probes actually confirm that a size larger than the
PTB_SIZE is supported by a path).[¶](#section-8-5){.pilcrow}

Parsing the quoted packet inside a PTB message can introduce additional
per-packet processing at the PL sender. This processing [SHOULD]{.bcp14}
be limited to avoid a denial-of-service attack when arbitrary headers
are included. Rate-limiting the processing could result in PTB messages
not being received by a PL; however, the DPLPMTUD method is robust to
such loss.[¶](#section-8-6){.pilcrow}

The successful processing of an ICMP message can trigger a probe when
the reported PTB size is valid, but this does not directly update the
PLPMTU for the path. This prevents a message attempting to black hole
data by indicating a size larger than supported by the
path.[¶](#section-8-7){.pilcrow}

It is possible that the information about a path is not stable. This
could be a result of forwarding across more than one path that has a
different actual PMTU or a single path presents a varying PMTU. The
design of a PLPMTUD implementation [SHOULD]{.bcp14} consider how to
mitigate the effects of varying path information. One possible
mitigation is to provide robustness (see [Section
5.4](#robustness){.xref}) in the method that avoids oscillation in the
MPS.[¶](#section-8-8){.pilcrow}

DPLPMTUD methods can introduce padding data to inflate the length of the
datagram to the total size required for a probe packet. The total size
of a probe packet includes all headers and padding added to the payload
data being sent (e.g., including security-related fields such as an AEAD
tag and TLS record layer padding). The value of the padding data does
not influence the DPLPMTUD search algorithm, and therefore needs to be
set consistent with the policy of the PL.[¶](#section-8-9){.pilcrow}

If a PL can make use of cryptographic confidentiality or data-integrity
mechanisms, then the design ought to avoid adding anything (e.g.,
padding) to DPLPMTUD probe packets that is not also protected by those
cryptographic mechanisms.[¶](#section-8-10){.pilcrow}
:::
:::

::: {#section-9 .section}
